name: Gas Town Documentation
description: Multi-agent orchestration for AI coding agents

pages.title: Getting Started
pages.description: This section covers everything you need to go from zero to running Gas Town with your first project.

pages.title: Installation
pages.description: Install Gas Town via Homebrew, npm, or build from source, plus required dependencies like Beads and tmux.

pages.title: Quick Start
pages.description: Set up your Gas Town workspace, add your first project, start the core agents, and give the Mayor your first instructions.

pages.title: Your First Convoy
pages.description: A Convoy is Gas Town's primary unit for tracking batches of related work. This walkthrough takes you through creating and monitoring your first convoy.

pages.title: Architecture
pages.description: Gas Town's architecture draws from Erlang's supervisor trees and mailbox patterns — battle-tested approaches to building reliable distributed systems.

pages.title: System Overview
pages.description: Gas Town consists of five layers:

pages.title: Agent Hierarchy
pages.description: Gas Town uses a supervisor tree pattern inspired by Erlang/OTP. Each agent level monitors the level below it, providing fault tolerance and automatic recovery.

pages.title: Work Distribution
pages.description: Every piece of work in Gas Town follows a defined lifecycle from creation to completion.

pages.title: Design Principles
pages.description: Gas Town is built on several core design principles that guide its architecture and behavior.

pages.title: CLI Reference
pages.description: The gt CLI is the primary interface for interacting with Gas Town. It manages workspaces, agents, work distribution, communication, and diagnostics across yo...

pages.title: Workspace Management
pages.description: Commands for installing, initializing, and managing your Gas Town workspace (the \

pages.title: Agent Operations
pages.description: Commands for starting, stopping, monitoring, and managing the Gas Town agent hierarchy. Each agent role has dedicated lifecycle commands, plus there are cros...

pages.title: Work Management
pages.description: Commands for creating, assigning, tracking, and completing work items. This includes both gt commands for work orchestration and bd (Beads) commands for issu...

pages.title: Convoy & Tracking
pages.description: Convoys are Gas Town's primary mechanism for bundling and tracking batches of related work. A convoy groups multiple beads together, monitors their collectiv...

pages.title: Communication
pages.description: Commands for inter-agent messaging, notifications, escalations, and broadcasts. Gas Town's communication layer is built on Erlang-inspired mailbox patterns w...

pages.title: Merge Queue
pages.description: Commands for managing the Refinery's merge queue. The Refinery processes merge requests (MRs) submitted by polecats, rebasing them onto the latest main branc...

pages.title: Rig Management
pages.description: Commands for adding, configuring, starting, stopping, and managing rigs. A rig is a project container that wraps a git repository with the full Gas Town agen...

pages.title: Session & Handoff
pages.description: Commands for managing agent sessions, handoffs between sessions, molecules (multi-step workflows), and formulas (reusable workflow templates).

pages.title: Diagnostics
pages.description: Commands for monitoring, auditing, and troubleshooting Gas Town. These tools provide visibility into system health, agent activity, resource usage, and opera...

pages.title: Configuration
pages.description: Commands for configuring agent runtimes, account settings, themes, hooks, and issue integration. These settings control how Gas Town operates at the town and...

pages.title: gt sling
pages.description: Assign work to agents and rigs. The primary command for work distribution in Gas Town, handling polecat spawning, formula instantiation, and batch dispatch.

pages.title: gt refinery
pages.description: Manage the Refinery, the per-rig merge queue processor that serializes all merges to main. Start, stop, monitor, and inspect merge requests.

pages.title: gt polecat
pages.description: Manage polecat lifecycle: list, inspect, nuke, garbage collect, detect stale workers, check recovery state, and manage identities.

pages.title: gt nudge
pages.description: Send synchronous messages directly to any worker's Claude Code session for real-time coordination between agents.

pages.title: gt session
pages.description: Manage tmux sessions for polecats: start, stop, restart, attach, monitor health, and capture output.

pages.title: Agents
pages.description: Gas Town's agent hierarchy is a supervisor tree inspired by Erlang/OTP. Each role has a well-defined scope, lifecycle, and set of responsibilities -- ensurin...

pages.title: Mayor -- Global Coordinator
pages.description: > The Mayor is the brain of Gas Town. It receives instructions from the human overseer, decomposes them into actionable work, and orchestrates the entire age...

pages.title: Deacon -- Town-Level Watchdog
pages.description: > The Deacon is the immune system of Gas Town. It monitors the health of every agent, manages lifecycles, and ensures the system self-heals when things go wr...

pages.title: Witness -- Per-Rig Health Monitor
pages.description: > The Witness is the local guardian of a rig. It watches every polecat in its domain, detects problems before they spread, and keeps the workspace clean.

pages.title: Refinery -- Merge Queue Processor
pages.description: > The Refinery is the gatekeeper of main. It serializes merges from concurrent polecats, ensuring every change is rebased, validated, and cleanly integrated.

pages.title: Polecats -- Ephemeral Workers
pages.description: > Polecats are the hands of Gas Town. They spawn, do their job, submit their work, and disappear. No idle time. No wasted resources.

pages.title: Dogs -- Infrastructure Workers
pages.description: > Dogs do the dirty work. They clean up messes, sync systems, and handle cross-rig infrastructure tasks that no single polecat or witness can manage alone.

pages.title: Crew -- Human Workspaces
pages.description: > Crew workspaces give human developers a first-class seat at the Gas Town table -- persistent, fully integrated, and always ready for hands-on work.

pages.title: Boot -- Daemon Watchdog Dog
pages.description: > Boot is the first responder. It runs fresh on every daemon tick, takes a snapshot of the world, and decides whether the Deacon needs waking or nudging.

pages.title: Core Concepts
pages.description: Gas Town is built on a small set of powerful primitives. Understanding these concepts is the key to effective use of the system, whether you are a human oper...

pages.title: Beads (Issue Tracking)
pages.description: Beads is Gas Town's AI-native, git-backed issue tracking system. Instead of a web-based project board, issues live directly in your repository as structured ...

pages.title: Hooks (Persistence)
pages.description: Hooks are Gas Town's durability primitive. A hook is a persistent attachment point where work state is stored in a way that survives crashes, restarts, hando...

pages.title: Convoys (Batch Tracking)
pages.description: A Convoy is Gas Town's unit for tracking batches of related work. Convoys bundle multiple beads together, provide a single point of progress monitoring, auto...

pages.title: Molecules & Formulas
pages.description: Molecules are Gas Town's multi-step workflow execution units. A molecule guides an agent through a sequence of steps, tracking progress so that work can resu...

pages.title: Gates (Async Coordination)
pages.description: Gates are synchronization points in Gas Town workflows. When a molecule step needs to wait for an external condition -- a CI pipeline finishing, a human appr...

pages.title: Rigs (Project Containers)
pages.description: A Rig is Gas Town's project container. Each rig wraps a git repository with the full agent infrastructure needed to manage, develop, and merge code. Rigs are...

pages.title: The MEOW Stack
pages.description: The MEOW Stack is Gas Town's layered abstraction model for organizing work, from atomic Beads to reusable Formulas.

pages.title: GUPP & NDI
pages.description: The Gas Town Universal Propulsion Principle (GUPP) and Nondeterministic Idempotence (NDI) are the core design principles that make Gas Town reliable at scale.

pages.title: Workflows
pages.description: Gas Town supports several workflow patterns for getting work done. Choose the one that best matches your needs and infrastructure.

pages.title: Mayor Workflow (MEOW)
pages.description: The Mayor Workflow -- also known as MEOW (Mayor-Executed Orchestrated Work) -- is the recommended workflow for complex multi-issue coordination. You describe...

pages.title: Minimal Mode (No Tmux)
pages.description: Minimal Mode lets you use Gas Town's persistence and tracking features without requiring Tmux or the full agent hierarchy. You manually spawn agents and mana...

pages.title: Manual Convoy Workflow
pages.description: The Manual Convoy Workflow gives you direct control over work distribution while still using Gas Town's convoy tracking, merge queue, and agent infrastructur...

pages.title: Formula Workflow
pages.description: The Formula Workflow uses predefined TOML templates to orchestrate structured, repeatable processes. Instead of describing work in free-form text, you select...

pages.title: Code Review Workflow
pages.description: Gas Town provides a powerful parallel code review system using the code-review convoy formula. Instead of a single reviewer reading through a PR, Gas Town sp...

pages.title: Operations
pages.description: Running Gas Town in production means managing a fleet of AI agents across multiple projects. This section covers the day-to-day operational tasks: starting a...

pages.description: Gas Town provides granular control over the system lifecycle -- from starting the entire fleet to managing individual agents and rigs. Understanding the dist...

pages.description: Gas Town provides a suite of monitoring tools to observe real-time activity, audit historical work, diagnose system health, and track costs. Effective monito...

pages.description: Gas Town's escalation system provides priority-routed alerts that flow upward through the supervision hierarchy. When an agent encounters a problem it cannot...

pages.description: This guide covers common Gas Town problems, their diagnosis, and resolution. Start with gt doctor for automated diagnostics, then consult the specific sectio...

pages.title: Plugins
pages.description: Gas Town's plugin system extends the platform with custom automation, gates, and scheduled tasks. Plugins can operate at the town level (affecting all rigs) ...

pages.title: Guides
pages.description: In-depth guides for using Gas Town effectively: usage patterns, architecture, cost management, multi-runtime support, and design philosophy.

pages.title: Usage Guide
pages.description: Practical day-to-day Gas Town usage patterns: entry points, the three developer loops, working with Mayor and Crew, the PR Sheriff pattern, 5 tips for effective use, and the mandatory landing checklist.

pages.title: The 8 Stages of AI Coding
pages.description: This guide maps out the progression of AI-assisted software development, from basic code completions to building your own multi-agent orchestrator. Gas Town ...

pages.title: Multi-Runtime Support
pages.description: Gas Town is not locked to a single AI coding agent. While Claude Code is the default and most thoroughly supported runtime, Gas Town supports multiple agent ...

pages.title: Cost Management
pages.description: Gas Town burns tokens. A lot of tokens. At peak usage with 10+ polecats running simultaneously, you can expect to spend approximately $100/hour -- roughly 10...

pages.title: Background & Philosophy
pages.description: Gas Town is not just a tool -- it is a thesis about the future of software development. This guide covers why Gas Town exists, how it evolved, the intellectual foundations behind its design, and the community response to its ideas.

pages.title: Architecture Guide
pages.description: A comprehensive tour of Gas Town's architecture: how Mayor, Deacon, Witness, Refinery, and Polecats work together as a self-healing multi-agent system built on Erlang-inspired supervision, git worktrees, and persistent hooks.

pages.title: Glossary
pages.description: Complete terminology reference for Gas Town, covering all agents, concepts, commands, and conventions.

pages.title: Troubleshooting
pages.description: Solutions for the most common Gas Town problems: gt done failures, polecat churn, branch naming, bead routing, hook conflicts, and stuck refineries.
